stem: A 55-year-old man who is diagnosed with COPD, complains of 1 week of fever and productive cough. Chest X-ray shows left upper lobe pneumonia. Sputum culture is positive for H. influenza. What is the antibiotic of choice?
disc:
Infective exacerbations of COPD are mostly due to S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae and M. catarrhalis. Therefore initial antibiotic of choice for an outpatient can be doxycycline or amoxicillin-clavulanic acid. Patients who are over 65 years or with frequent exacerbations mostly require the latter or a newer generation of fluoroquinolone.

Inward patients mostly receive 3rd generation cephalosporins, fluoroquinolones or macrolides. For more severe infections, treatment should include a third-generation cephalosporin or augmented penicillin, plus a fluoroquinolone or an aminoglycoside for synergy.
